                                            By 
                                                    Josh Zeitz


                                            By 
                                                    Rich Lowry


                                            By 
Jack Shafer


                                            By 
                                                    Steven Lee Myers


                AP Photo

            By 
Kimberly Hefling

10/01/15 01:48 PM EDT
The political arm of the nation’s largest labor union on Thursday gave Hillary Clinton its support for president, paving the way for the National Education Association to endorse the Democratic frontrunner.
The NEA's PAC recommended that the union's board endorse her, which could happen as early as the end of this week.
Story Continued Below
Some of the union's affiliates have asked the union to hold back on an endorsement as the race for the Democratic nomination becomes more unpredictable. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders has been mounting a surprisingly competitive challenge: His campaign reported this week that he’d raised almost as much as Clinton in the most recent fundraising quarter. Meanwhile, Vice President Joe Biden, a longtime union supporter, is weighing a presidential run. 
The American Federation of Teachers — whose president is longtime Clinton ally Randi Weingarten — came out this summer in support of Clinton. That frustrated other unions and even some of AFT's own members who felt the union was fast-tracking amid a surge by Sanders what should be a more deliberate process.



            By 
Nick Gass

On the campaign trail, and even before her bid, Clinton has been a strong supporter of early childhood education programs. At one of her first campaign stops she said she supports the concept of the Common Core standards. But on education, her campaign has largely focused on college affordability issues when addressing education. K-12 education in recent years has been a tricky issue for Democrats, dividing the party’s historically allied teachers unions and so-called “reformers” who back charter schools and other forms of school choice and using strong accountability measures such as test scores to evaluate teachers and schools. 
The NEA sat out the contentious 2008 Democratic primary between Clinton and then-Sen. Barack Obama, only later endorsing Obama for the general election. Some union members later felt NEA had missed out on an opportunity to be big league power brokers.
Later, NEA would clash with many of the Obama administration initiatives such as incentivizing states to adopt teacher evaluations systems tied in test scores. In 2014, the union went so far as to pass a resolution calling for the resignation of Education Secretary Arne Duncan. 
Last month, the NEA in New Hampshire also endorsed Clinton. But support for a Clinton endorsement within NEA’s rank-and-file isn’t widespread. Vermont’s NEA chapter endorsed Sanders in June. NEA chapters in Massachusetts, New Jersey, Nebraska urged the national council to wait before acting. 
“We are concerned that an early recommendation does not allow members to be participants in a real debate around the issues that are still unfolding,” said Nancy Fulton, the president of the NEA in Nebraska in a statement. 
Only Clinton, Sanders and Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley were considered by the group because they opted to participate in the union’s endorsement process.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: NEA's political arm recommends Clinton endorsement
